awd_titl_txt: Problems in Extremal Combinatorics and Finite Geometry
awd_abstract_narration:
The PI will develop algebraic tools for solving problems in extremal combinatorics and finite geometry, which are two important subareas of combinatorics. Combinatorics is an area of mathematics primarily concerned with properties of finite structures. It is closely related to many other areas of mathematics and has many applications ranging from logic to statistical physics, from evolutionary biology to computer science, etc.

This project will focus on three types of problems in finite geometry and extremal combinatorics. The PI intends to give improved upper bounds on the sizes of partial spreads, partial ovoids, and 1-systems in some classical polar spaces by using matrix rank argument. These bounds in turn will lead to non-existence proofs of ovoids in certain classical polar spaces. The Erdos-Ko-Rado theorem is a cornerstone in extremal combinatorics. Generalizations of the Erdos-Ko-Rado theorem hold for many different objects that have a notion of intersection. The PI will consider Erdos-Ko-Rado type problems for permutation groups. In the third part of the project, the PI will investigate constructions of difference sets, strongly regular Cayley graphs and related geometric substructures in classical polar spaces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The research carried out under the auspices of this grant led to significant advances in extremal combinatorics, projective geometry and information security. Results connected to finite field theory, graph theory and coding theory were also obtained. 

The most important results of the grant centered on projective geometry, where two long-standing problems were significantly advanced. The problem of constructing m-ovoids had seen little advancement in many years. In a collaborative effort, the original PI of the project found a new construction method that produced many new examples. The problem of classifying planar monomials over finite fields has been an open problem for over fifty years. The replacement PI provided the first significant result on the topic in a decade in another collaborative work. Further work from the project led to the formulation of a new concept in information security which has the potential to significantly impact the way in which researchers approach the central problem of constructing bijective functions with high resistance to differential cryptanalysis.

In terms of broader impacts, the project had significant graduate student involvement. Over the course of the project, 5 Ph.D. students completed their studies with an additional two due to complete within the next year. Additionally, the research of the project was disseminated in 12 articles (8 published, 4 still in submission) and in at least 10 presentations at international conferences and institutional seminar series.


Last Modified: 01/06/2023
Modified by: Robert S Coulter
